Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar A couple of years ago I started using Twitter, and one of the things that really charmed me about Twitter is that people would wake up in the morning and they would say, "Good morning!" which I thought, I'm a Canadian, so I was a little bit, I liked that politeness. And so, I'm also a giant nerd, and so I wrote a computer program that would record 24 hours of everybody on Twitter saying, "Good morning!" And then I asked myself my favorite question, "What would that look like?" Well, as it turns out, I think it would look something like this. Right, so we'd see this wave of people saying, "Good morning!" across the world as they wake up. Now the green people, these are people that wake up at around 8 o'clock in the morning, Who wakes up at 8 o'clock or says, "Good morning!" at 8? And the orange people, they say, "Good morning!" around 9. And the red people, they say, "Good morning!" around 10. Yeah, more at 10's than, more at 10's than 8's. And actually if you look at this map, we can learn a little bit about how people wake up in different parts of the world. People on the West Coast, for example, they wake up a little bit later than those people on the East Coast. But that's not all that people say on Twitter, right? We also get these really important tweets, like, "I just landed in Orlando!! [plane sign, plane sign]" Or, or, "I just landed in Texas [exclamation point]!" Or "I just landed in Honduras!" These lists, they go on and on and on, all these people, right? So, on the outside, these people are just telling us something about how they're traveling. But we know the truth, don't we? These people are show-offs! They are showing off that they're in Cape Town and I'm not. So I thought, how can we take this vanity and turn it into utility? So using a similar approach that I did with "Good morning," I mapped all those people's trips because I know where they're landing, they just told me, and I know where they live because they share that information on their Twitter profile. So what I'm able to do with 36 hours of Twitter is create a model of how people are traveling around the world during that 36 hours. And this is kind of a prototype because I think if we listen to everybody on Twitter and Facebook and the rest of our social media, we'd actually get a pretty clear picture of how people are traveling from one place to the other, which is actually turns out to be a very useful thing for scientists, particularly those who are studying how disease is spread. So, I work upstairs in the New York Times, and for the last two years, we've been working on a project called, "Cascade," which in some ways is kind of similar to this one. But instead of modeling how people move, we're modeling how people talk. We're looking at what does a discussion look like. Well, here's an example. This is a discussion around an article called, "The Island Where People Forget to Die". It's about an island in Greece where people live a really, really, really, really, really, really long time. And what we're seeing here is we're seeing a conversation that's stemming from that first tweet down in the bottom, left-hand corner. So we get to see the scope of this conversation over about 9 hours right now, we're going to creep up to 12 hours here in a second. But, we can also see what that conversation looks like in three dimensions. And that three-dimensional view is actually much more useful for us. As humans, we are really used to things that are structured as three dimensions. So, we can look at those little off-shoots of conversation, we can find out what exactly happened. And this is an interactive, exploratory tool so we can go through every step in the conversation. We can look at who the people were, what they said, how old they are, where they live, who follows them, and so on, and so on, and so on. So, the Times creates about 6,500 pieces of content every month, and we can model every single one of the conversations that happen around them. And they look somewhat different. Depending on the story and depending on how fast people are talking about it and how far the conversation spreads, these structures, which I call these conversational architectures, end up looking different. So, these projects that I've shown you, I think they all involve the same thing: we can take small pieces of data and by putting them together, we can generate more value, we can do more exciting things with them. But so far we've only talked about Twitter, right? And Twitter isn't all the data. We learned a moment ago that there is tons and tons, tons more data out there. And specifically, I want you to think about one type of data because all of you guys, everybody in this audience, we, we, me as well, are data-making machines. We are producing data all the time. Every single one of us, we're producing data. Somebody else, though, is storing that data. Usually we put our trust into companies to store that data, but what I want to suggest here is that rather than putting our trust in companies to store that data, we should put the trust in ourselves because we actually own that data. Right, that is something we should remember. Everything that someone else measures about you, you actually own. So, it's my hope, maybe because I'm a Canadian, that all of us can come together with this really valuable data that we've been storing, and we can collectively launch that data toward some of the world's most difficulty problems because big data can solve big problems, but I think it can do it the best if it's all of us who are in control. Thank you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Thorp's map of people saying good morning, who sleeps until later in the day?
Options: A. New York City, B. East Coast, C. West Coast, D. Midwest
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What initially charmed the speaker about Twitter? Options: A. The ability to share opinions on various topics, B. The politeness of users, such as saying "Good morning!", C. The vast amount of data available, D. The option to share travel experiences Correct Option: B
Question 2: What did the speaker create by mapping people's tweets saying "Good morning!" across the world? Options: A. A model of how people travel, B. A conversational architecture, C. A wave-like pattern showing when people wake up, D. A map of Twitter users' locations Correct Option: C
Question 3: According to the speaker, what can be learned from analyzing tweets about people's travel experiences? Options: A. How people wake up at different times, B. How disease is spread, C. How people engage in conversations on Twitter, D. How to create a model of human migration patterns Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the project the speaker worked on at The New York Times? Options: A. Cascade, B. Conversational Architectures, C. Twitter Travel, D. Good Morning Map Correct Option: A
Question 5: What does the speaker's project "Cascade" aim to model? Options: A. How people move around the world, B. How people talk and engage in conversations, C. How disease is spread, D. How people wake up at different times Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the benefit of viewing conversations in three dimensions, according to the speaker? Options: A. It allows for more data to be collected, B. It provides a clearer picture of how people travel, C. It enables humans to better understand structured conversations, D. It creates a more interactive and exploratory tool Correct Option: C
Question 7: How many pieces of content does The New York Times create every month, according to the speaker? Options: A. 1,000, B. 6,500, C. 10,000, D. 50,000 Correct Option: B
Question 8: What does the speaker suggest people should do with their personal data? Options: A. Trust companies to store it, B. Share it publicly on social media, C. Put trust in themselves and take control of it, D. Delete it to maintain privacy Correct Option: C
Question 9: According to the speaker, what can be achieved by collectively using personal data to tackle problems? Options: A. Creating more conversational architectures, B. Modeling how people move around the world, C. Solving big problems more effectively, D. Creating more Twitter bots Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the speaker's hope for the future of personal data, as expressed in the talk? Options: A. That companies will take control of storing and managing it, B. That people will delete their data to maintain privacy, C. That individuals will come together to use their data to solve big problems, D. That social media platforms will become more secure Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar A couple of years ago I started using Twitter, and one of the things that really charmed me about Twitter is that people would wake up in the morning and they would say, "Good morning!" which I thought, I'm a Canadian, so I was a little bit, I liked that politeness. And so, I'm also a giant nerd, and so I wrote a computer program that would record 24 hours of everybody on Twitter saying, "Good morning!" And then I asked myself my favorite question, "What would that look like?" Well, as it turns out, I think it would look something like this. Right, so we'd see this wave of people saying, "Good morning!" across the world as they wake up. Now the green people, these are people that wake up at around 8 o'clock in the morning, Who wakes up at 8 o'clock or says, "Good morning!" at 8? And the orange people, they say, "Good morning!" around 9. And the red people, they say, "Good morning!" around 10. Yeah, more at 10's than, more at 10's than 8's. And actually if you look at this map, we can learn a little bit about how people wake up in different parts of the world. People on the West Coast, for example, they wake up a little bit later than those people on the East Coast. But that's not all that people say on Twitter, right? We also get these really important tweets, like, "I just landed in Orlando!! [plane sign, plane sign]" Or, or, "I just landed in Texas [exclamation point]!" Or "I just landed in Honduras!" These lists, they go on and on and on, all these people, right? So, on the outside, these people are just telling us something about how they're traveling. But we know the truth, don't we? These people are show-offs! They are showing off that they're in Cape Town and I'm not. So I thought, how can we take this vanity and turn it into utility? So using a similar approach that I did with "Good morning," I mapped all those people's trips because I know where they're landing, they just told me, and I know where they live because they share that information on their Twitter profile. So what I'm able to do with 36 hours of Twitter is create a model of how people are traveling around the world during that 36 hours. And this is kind of a prototype because I think if we listen to everybody on Twitter and Facebook and the rest of our social media, we'd actually get a pretty clear picture of how people are traveling from one place to the other, which is actually turns out to be a very useful thing for scientists, particularly those who are studying how disease is spread. So, I work upstairs in the New York Times, and for the last two years, we've been working on a project called, "Cascade," which in some ways is kind of similar to this one. But instead of modeling how people move, we're modeling how people talk. We're looking at what does a discussion look like. Well, here's an example. This is a discussion around an article called, "The Island Where People Forget to Die". It's about an island in Greece where people live a really, really, really, really, really, really long time. And what we're seeing here is we're seeing a conversation that's stemming from that first tweet down in the bottom, left-hand corner. So we get to see the scope of this conversation over about 9 hours right now, we're going to creep up to 12 hours here in a second. But, we can also see what that conversation looks like in three dimensions. And that three-dimensional view is actually much more useful for us. As humans, we are really used to things that are structured as three dimensions. So, we can look at those little off-shoots of conversation, we can find out what exactly happened. And this is an interactive, exploratory tool so we can go through every step in the conversation. We can look at who the people were, what they said, how old they are, where they live, who follows them, and so on, and so on, and so on. So, the Times creates about 6,500 pieces of content every month, and we can model every single one of the conversations that happen around them. And they look somewhat different. Depending on the story and depending on how fast people are talking about it and how far the conversation spreads, these structures, which I call these conversational architectures, end up looking different. So, these projects that I've shown you, I think they all involve the same thing: we can take small pieces of data and by putting them together, we can generate more value, we can do more exciting things with them. But so far we've only talked about Twitter, right? And Twitter isn't all the data. We learned a moment ago that there is tons and tons, tons more data out there. And specifically, I want you to think about one type of data because all of you guys, everybody in this audience, we, we, me as well, are data-making machines. We are producing data all the time. Every single one of us, we're producing data. Somebody else, though, is storing that data. Usually we put our trust into companies to store that data, but what I want to suggest here is that rather than putting our trust in companies to store that data, we should put the trust in ourselves because we actually own that data. Right, that is something we should remember. Everything that someone else measures about you, you actually own. So, it's my hope, maybe because I'm a Canadian, that all of us can come together with this really valuable data that we've been storing, and we can collectively launch that data toward some of the world's most difficulty problems because big data can solve big problems, but I think it can do it the best if it's all of us who are in control. Thank you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: About how much content does the New York Times create every month?
Options: A. 100 pieces, B. 1 million pieces, C. 6,500 pieces, D. 1,000 pieces
Correct Option: C

Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar A couple of years ago I started using Twitter, and one of the things that really charmed me about Twitter is that people would wake up in the morning and they would say, "Good morning!" which I thought, I'm a Canadian, so I was a little bit, I liked that politeness. And so, I'm also a giant nerd, and so I wrote a computer program that would record 24 hours of everybody on Twitter saying, "Good morning!" And then I asked myself my favorite question, "What would that look like?" Well, as it turns out, I think it would look something like this. Right, so we'd see this wave of people saying, "Good morning!" across the world as they wake up. Now the green people, these are people that wake up at around 8 o'clock in the morning, Who wakes up at 8 o'clock or says, "Good morning!" at 8? And the orange people, they say, "Good morning!" around 9. And the red people, they say, "Good morning!" around 10. Yeah, more at 10's than, more at 10's than 8's. And actually if you look at this map, we can learn a little bit about how people wake up in different parts of the world. People on the West Coast, for example, they wake up a little bit later than those people on the East Coast. But that's not all that people say on Twitter, right? We also get these really important tweets, like, "I just landed in Orlando!! [plane sign, plane sign]" Or, or, "I just landed in Texas [exclamation point]!" Or "I just landed in Honduras!" These lists, they go on and on and on, all these people, right? So, on the outside, these people are just telling us something about how they're traveling. But we know the truth, don't we? These people are show-offs! They are showing off that they're in Cape Town and I'm not. So I thought, how can we take this vanity and turn it into utility? So using a similar approach that I did with "Good morning," I mapped all those people's trips because I know where they're landing, they just told me, and I know where they live because they share that information on their Twitter profile. So what I'm able to do with 36 hours of Twitter is create a model of how people are traveling around the world during that 36 hours. And this is kind of a prototype because I think if we listen to everybody on Twitter and Facebook and the rest of our social media, we'd actually get a pretty clear picture of how people are traveling from one place to the other, which is actually turns out to be a very useful thing for scientists, particularly those who are studying how disease is spread. So, I work upstairs in the New York Times, and for the last two years, we've been working on a project called, "Cascade," which in some ways is kind of similar to this one. But instead of modeling how people move, we're modeling how people talk. We're looking at what does a discussion look like. Well, here's an example. This is a discussion around an article called, "The Island Where People Forget to Die". It's about an island in Greece where people live a really, really, really, really, really, really long time. And what we're seeing here is we're seeing a conversation that's stemming from that first tweet down in the bottom, left-hand corner. So we get to see the scope of this conversation over about 9 hours right now, we're going to creep up to 12 hours here in a second. But, we can also see what that conversation looks like in three dimensions. And that three-dimensional view is actually much more useful for us. As humans, we are really used to things that are structured as three dimensions. So, we can look at those little off-shoots of conversation, we can find out what exactly happened. And this is an interactive, exploratory tool so we can go through every step in the conversation. We can look at who the people were, what they said, how old they are, where they live, who follows them, and so on, and so on, and so on. So, the Times creates about 6,500 pieces of content every month, and we can model every single one of the conversations that happen around them. And they look somewhat different. Depending on the story and depending on how fast people are talking about it and how far the conversation spreads, these structures, which I call these conversational architectures, end up looking different. So, these projects that I've shown you, I think they all involve the same thing: we can take small pieces of data and by putting them together, we can generate more value, we can do more exciting things with them. But so far we've only talked about Twitter, right? And Twitter isn't all the data. We learned a moment ago that there is tons and tons, tons more data out there. And specifically, I want you to think about one type of data because all of you guys, everybody in this audience, we, we, me as well, are data-making machines. We are producing data all the time. Every single one of us, we're producing data. Somebody else, though, is storing that data. Usually we put our trust into companies to store that data, but what I want to suggest here is that rather than putting our trust in companies to store that data, we should put the trust in ourselves because we actually own that data. Right, that is something we should remember. Everything that someone else measures about you, you actually own. So, it's my hope, maybe because I'm a Canadian, that all of us can come together with this really valuable data that we've been storing, and we can collectively launch that data toward some of the world's most difficulty problems because big data can solve big problems, but I think it can do it the best if it's all of us who are in control. Thank you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Thorp, you own data that's gathered:
Options: A. Anytime somebody measures something about you, B. When the government enlists you to be involved in a study, C. Only in a study that you conduct yourself, D. That doesn't include any information based on variables outside of yourself or your personal property
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Fourth and nineteen, folks, they've gotta have a play as time's ticking away because they've got to stay in this ball game, they've got to win. They come out lined up in the empty set, three receivers to the right, two to the left. Defense looks like they're gonna to man up with no safety. This is the exact offensive match-up that they want: the best receiver lined up against the linebacker. Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun. He takes a snap, drops three steps, he plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush. He's looking down field. He's got the inside receiver making a cut. He's got a step on the linebacker. Quarterback has a beat on it. He lets the ball go, it's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender. He's got it beat! He's out in front, racing for the ball! It's coming down! He cradles it at the fifteen! He's at the ten, five! Touchdown! Unbelievable play! Now, wait a minute. Of course, it's believable, it's physics, specifically the differences between scalars and vectors. So, let's just see that replay. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Stop. See, measurements are defined as two different quantities. Scalars are measurements with only numbers, and vectors are measurements with direction. For example, when that quarterback takes the snap, he's five yards away, but from where? Back from the line of scrimmage, so the five yards by itself is a scalar quantity. When you add a direction, like five yards deep, it becomes a vector quantity. Five yards - scalar, five yards deep - vector. OK, go ahead. "He takes a snap, drops three steps. He plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Whoa! Here's a difference between distance and displacement. Distance is a measurement without identifying where you moved. It's a scalar quantity. When the quarterback makes a three-step drop, he moves about three yards back. When he moves about another three yards forward, when he steps up into the pocket, so that quarterback moves a total distance of six yards. That's a distance, that's a scalar. Now, displacement is a vector quantity, describing about how far out of place the object is. So the quarterback dropped back three yards and then moved back forward three yards, he's in the exact same place where he started. So, his displacement is zero yards. Distance - six yards, displacement - zero yards. So, let's look at what happened next. "Quarterback has a beat on it, he let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender." Stop. So, here's speed and velocity, but let's just do one thing at a time. So, speed is measurement without direction, it's a scalar quantity. Velocity is a vector quantity. It is that object's speed, but with a direction of motion. So the receiver accelerates away, gaining both speed and distance. This takes the receiver 5 seconds to run those 50 yards. So his average speed, in any given time, is 10 yards/second. The linebacker tries to keep up, but his overall speed is slower, he only goes 35 yards in those 5 seconds, so his average speed is only 7 yards/second. They're both traveling in a forward direction, so their velocity is also positive. You can't go from resting to your peak speed immediately. You've got to build up to it. This is acceleration. At first the linebacker can keep up with that receiver, but eventually the faster receiver pulls away. That's acceleration, the change in speed over time. Acceleration is a vector quantity. It describes a rate at which an object changes velocity. Like velocity, acceleration is a vector. It happens in a direction. So let's just look at that play just one more time. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Vector! "He takes a snap, drops three steps, he plants his back foot. He's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Displacement! "He's got the inside receiver making a cut. He's got a step on the linebacker. The quarterback has a beat on it. He let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender!" Velocity! "He's got it beat! He's out in front, racing for the ball! It's coming down! He cradles it at the fifteen, he's at the ten, five!" Acceleration! "Touchdown! Unbelievable play! That was a great play as time expired, resulting in the touchdown and ultimately the win and pure effort." And pure science.

Correct Option: B

Question 1: What is the primary difference between scalars and vectors in physics? Options: A. Scalars are measurements with direction, while vectors are measurements without direction., B. Scalars are measurements of speed, while vectors are measurements of velocity. Correct Option: B

Distance is a scalar quantity, while displacement is a vector quantity., C. Distance is a measurement of speed, while displacement is a measurement of velocity., D. Speed is a measurement of acceleration, while velocity is a measurement of deceleration. Correct Option: B
Question 6: A linebacker accelerates from rest to a speed of 7 yards/second in 5 seconds. What can be concluded about his acceleration? Options: A. His acceleration is constant., B. His acceleration is increasing., C. His acceleration is decreasing., D. His acceleration is zero. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does the concept of acceleration apply to the receiver's motion in the play? Options: A. The receiver accelerates from rest to his peak speed immediately., B. The receiver accelerates from rest to his peak speed over a period of time., C. The receiver decelerates from his peak speed to rest., D. The receiver maintains a constant speed throughout the play. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the relationship between velocity and acceleration? Options: A. Velocity is the rate of change of acceleration., B. Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity., C. Velocity is a scalar quantity, while acceleration is a vector quantity., D. Velocity is a vector quantity, while acceleration is a scalar quantity. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How does the concept of vectors apply to the quarterback's motion in the play? Options: A. The quarterback's motion is an example of a scalar quantity., B. The quarterback's motion is an example of a vector quantity., C. The quarterback's motion is an example of a distance measurement., D. The quarterback's motion is an example of a displacement measurement. Correct Option: B

Question 8 states that acceleration is the rate of change of velocity, which implies the concept of velocity as a vector quantity that can be determined by dividing displacement by time.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Fourth and nineteen, folks, they've gotta have a play as time's ticking away because they've got to stay in this ball game, they've got to win. They come out lined up in the empty set, three receivers to the right, two to the left. Defense looks like they're gonna to man up with no safety. This is the exact offensive match-up that they want: the best receiver lined up against the linebacker. Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun. He takes a snap, drops three steps, he plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush. He's looking down field. He's got the inside receiver making a cut. He's got a step on the linebacker. Quarterback has a beat on it. He lets the ball go, it's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender. He's got it beat! He's out in front, racing for the ball! It's coming down! He cradles it at the fifteen! He's at the ten, five! Touchdown! Unbelievable play! Now, wait a minute. Of course, it's believable, it's physics, specifically the differences between scalars and vectors. So, let's just see that replay. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Stop. See, measurements are defined as two different quantities. Scalars are measurements with only numbers, and vectors are measurements with direction. For example, when that quarterback takes the snap, he's five yards away, but from where? Back from the line of scrimmage, so the five yards by itself is a scalar quantity. When you add a direction, like five yards deep, it becomes a vector quantity. Five yards - scalar, five yards deep - vector. OK, go ahead. "He takes a snap, drops three steps. He plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Whoa! Here's a difference between distance and displacement. Distance is a measurement without identifying where you moved. It's a scalar quantity. When the quarterback makes a three-step drop, he moves about three yards back. When he moves about another three yards forward, when he steps up into the pocket, so that quarterback moves a total distance of six yards. That's a distance, that's a scalar. Now, displacement is a vector quantity, describing about how far out of place the object is. So the quarterback dropped back three yards and then moved back forward three yards, he's in the exact same place where he started. So, his displacement is zero yards. Distance - six yards, displacement - zero yards. So, let's look at what happened next. "Quarterback has a beat on it, he let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender." Stop. So, here's speed and velocity, but let's just do one thing at a time. So, speed is measurement without direction, it's a scalar quantity. Velocity is a vector quantity. It is that object's speed, but with a direction of motion. So the receiver accelerates away, gaining both speed and distance. This takes the receiver 5 seconds to run those 50 yards. So his average speed, in any given time, is 10 yards/second. The linebacker tries to keep up, but his overall speed is slower, he only goes 35 yards in those 5 seconds, so his average speed is only 7 yards/second. They're both traveling in a forward direction, so their velocity is also positive. You can't go from resting to your peak speed immediately. You've got to build up to it. This is acceleration. At first the linebacker can keep up with that receiver, but eventually the faster receiver pulls away. That's acceleration, the change in speed over time. Acceleration is a vector quantity. It describes a rate at which an object changes velocity. Like velocity, acceleration is a vector. It happens in a direction. So let's just look at that play just one more time. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Vector! "He takes a snap, drops three steps, he plants his back foot. He's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Displacement! "He's got the inside receiver making a cut. He's got a step on the linebacker. The quarterback has a beat on it. He let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender!" Velocity! "He's got it beat! He's out in front, racing for the ball! It's coming down! He cradles it at the fifteen, he's at the ten, five!" Acceleration! "Touchdown! Unbelievable play! That was a great play as time expired, resulting in the touchdown and ultimately the win and pure effort." And pure science.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What principle describes why you can't go from resting to your peak speed immediately?
Options: A. Velocity, B. Displacement, C. Trajectory, D. Acceleration
Correct Option: D

Scalars are measurements of speed, while vectors are measurements of velocity. Correct Option: B

Distance is a scalar quantity, while displacement is a vector quantity., C. Distance is a measurement of speed, while displacement is a measurement of velocity., D. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Ever see a medieval painting of baby Jesus sitting or standing on his mother's lap and wonder why she's so large? Paintings like Cimabue's enthroned Madonna with angels or Duccio's Maesta also appear out of proportion. If Mary were to stand up, it seems, the angels in the picture would be as tall as her shin bone, and her torso would be disproportionately small when compared to her legs. Maybe you thought the artist simply wasn't skilled enough to paint realistically or lacked the mathematical skill of perspective. But that's not the full story. To understand why, we need to go back to the late fifth century when the city of Rome was attacked by the Goths. Rome was built in marble and meant to last forever. It represented, for many years, the pinnacle of human civilization, so its destruction left a huge void. Theologians, who preached about a world beyond the physical, began attracting an audience as Rome crumbled, and Christianity started to fill the void left by the Empire. As a replacement for the physical beauty of Rome, Christianity offered a metaphysical beauty of virtue and an eternal heaven that could not be destroyed as Rome had. After the fall of Rome, early medieval theologians turned away from physical beauty, rejecting it in favor of inner-beauty. They maintained that while the physical world was temporary, virtue and religion were permanent. Beautiful objects could lead to a misguided worship of the object rather than the worship of goodness. It is said that the early sixth century preacher, St. Benedict, upon thinking of a beautiful woman, threw himself into a thorn patch, and through his suffering, regained his focus on spiritual beauty. He feared his desire for the beautiful woman would distract him from his desire to love God. As European civilization transitioned away from empires and towards religion, monasteries became the gatekeepers of knowledge, which meant that classical books that praised physical pleasures were not copied or protected. Without protection, they became the victims of natural decay, fire, flooding, or pests. And without the help of monks transcribing new copies, these texts and the philosophies they carried disappeared in Western Europe and were replaced by the works of people like St. Benedict, which brings us back to these depictions of Jesus and Mary. Because Christianity had so fervently rejected physical beauty, these medieval artists purposefully avoided aesthetically pleasing forms. At first, decorations for churches or palaces were limited to interesting geometric patterns, which could be pleasing without inspiring sinful thoughts of physical pleasure. As the medieval period progressed, depictions of Jesus and Mary were tolerated, but the artist clearly made an effort to veil Mary and give her disproportionately large legs, with those enormous shin bones. The fear remained that a beautiful illustration of Mary might inspire the viewer to love the painting or the physical form of Mary, rather than the virtue she's meant to represent. So even though it may be fun to think we can paint more realistically than Cimabuey or Duccio, we need to remember that they had different goals when picking up a paintbrush.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What prominent figure in Medieval paintings was commonly painted out of proportion?
Options: A. Mary, the mother of Jesus, B. David, the shepherd boy, C. Gabriel, the angel, D. Venus, the Roman goddess
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the artist behind the painting "Enthroned Madonna with Angels"? Options: A. Duccio, B. Cimabue, C. St. Benedict, D. Leonardo da Vinci Correct Option: B
Question 2: What event in the late fifth century led to the decline of physical beauty in art and the rise of metaphysical beauty in Christianity? Options: A. The construction of the city of Rome, B. The attack on Rome by the Goths, C. The discovery of perspective in art, D. The birth of Jesus Christ Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to early medieval theologians, what was considered temporary, and what was considered permanent? Options: A. Physical beauty was permanent, and virtue was temporary, B. Physical beauty was temporary, and virtue was permanent, C. Both physical beauty and virtue were temporary, D. Both physical beauty and virtue were permanent Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did St. Benedict throw himself into a thorn patch upon thinking of a beautiful woman? Options: A. He wanted to punish himself for his sinful thoughts, B. He wanted to prove his love for God, C. He feared his desire for the woman would distract him from his spiritual goals, D. He wanted to test his physical endurance Correct Option: C
Question 5: What happened to classical books that praised physical pleasures during the transition from empires to religion in European civilization? Options: A. They were widely copied and protected by monks, B. They were ignored but still survived through the centuries, C. They were not copied or protected and eventually disappeared, D. They were translated into vernacular languages Correct Option: C
Question 6: Why did medieval artists purposefully avoid aesthetically pleasing forms in their depictions of Jesus and Mary? Options: A. They lacked the skill to paint realistically, B. They wanted to emphasize the physical beauty of their subjects, C. They feared that beautiful illustrations might inspire sinful thoughts, D. They were only interested in depicting geometric patterns Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the primary goal of medieval artists when depicting Jesus and Mary, and how did it differ from modern artistic goals? Options: A. Medieval artists aimed to create realistic and beautiful depictions, while modern artists focus on abstract representations, B. Medieval artists sought to convey spiritual beauty, while modern artists prioritize physical beauty, C. Medieval artists aimed to tell stories through their art, while modern artists focus on expressing emotions, D. Medieval artists sought to create decorative pieces, while modern artists aim to create thought-provoking works Correct Option: B
Question 8: How did the rise of Christianity influence the development of art in Western Europe during the medieval period? Options: A. Christianity led to a renewed focus on physical beauty and realism in art, B. Christianity resulted in a decline in artistic production and innovation, C. Christianity led to a shift away from physical beauty and towards metaphysical and spiritual themes, D. Christianity had no significant impact on the development of art in Western Europe Correct Option: C
Question 9: What would be a likely consequence of an artist creating a beautiful and realistic depiction of Mary during the medieval period? Options: A. The artist would be praised for their skill and devotion to their craft, B. The artist would be accused of promoting sinful thoughts and desires, C. The artist would be ignored by the art community and the Church, D. The artist would be asked to create more works in a similar style Correct Option: B
Question 10: How can the depictions of Jesus and Mary in medieval art be seen as a reflection of the societal values and priorities of the time? Options: A. They demonstrate a focus on physical beauty and material wealth, B. They reflect a emphasis on spiritual beauty and virtue, C. They show a lack of artistic skill and technique, D. They represent a desire for realism and accuracy in art Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6. However, the options in Question 6 do not directly match the ground truth MCQ. 

A more suitable match is not present among the generated MCQs as none of them directly ask about the prominent figure in medieval paintings being painted out of proportion. However, if we consider the intent and the subject matter, Question 6 is the closest match.

But if we consider the entire set of generated MCQs and try to find the one that at least mentions "Mary" as an option or in the question, we can consider Question 7. It talks about the depiction of Jesus and Mary but does not specifically mention the proportion issue.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Ever see a medieval painting of baby Jesus sitting or standing on his mother's lap and wonder why she's so large? Paintings like Cimabue's enthroned Madonna with angels or Duccio's Maesta also appear out of proportion. If Mary were to stand up, it seems, the angels in the picture would be as tall as her shin bone, and her torso would be disproportionately small when compared to her legs. Maybe you thought the artist simply wasn't skilled enough to paint realistically or lacked the mathematical skill of perspective. But that's not the full story. To understand why, we need to go back to the late fifth century when the city of Rome was attacked by the Goths. Rome was built in marble and meant to last forever. It represented, for many years, the pinnacle of human civilization, so its destruction left a huge void. Theologians, who preached about a world beyond the physical, began attracting an audience as Rome crumbled, and Christianity started to fill the void left by the Empire. As a replacement for the physical beauty of Rome, Christianity offered a metaphysical beauty of virtue and an eternal heaven that could not be destroyed as Rome had. After the fall of Rome, early medieval theologians turned away from physical beauty, rejecting it in favor of inner-beauty. They maintained that while the physical world was temporary, virtue and religion were permanent. Beautiful objects could lead to a misguided worship of the object rather than the worship of goodness. It is said that the early sixth century preacher, St. Benedict, upon thinking of a beautiful woman, threw himself into a thorn patch, and through his suffering, regained his focus on spiritual beauty. He feared his desire for the beautiful woman would distract him from his desire to love God. As European civilization transitioned away from empires and towards religion, monasteries became the gatekeepers of knowledge, which meant that classical books that praised physical pleasures were not copied or protected. Without protection, they became the victims of natural decay, fire, flooding, or pests. And without the help of monks transcribing new copies, these texts and the philosophies they carried disappeared in Western Europe and were replaced by the works of people like St. Benedict, which brings us back to these depictions of Jesus and Mary. Because Christianity had so fervently rejected physical beauty, these medieval artists purposefully avoided aesthetically pleasing forms. At first, decorations for churches or palaces were limited to interesting geometric patterns, which could be pleasing without inspiring sinful thoughts of physical pleasure. As the medieval period progressed, depictions of Jesus and Mary were tolerated, but the artist clearly made an effort to veil Mary and give her disproportionately large legs, with those enormous shin bones. The fear remained that a beautiful illustration of Mary might inspire the viewer to love the painting or the physical form of Mary, rather than the virtue she's meant to represent. So even though it may be fun to think we can paint more realistically than Cimabuey or Duccio, we need to remember that they had different goals when picking up a paintbrush.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What first populated art spaces in churches and palaces after the fall of Rome?
Options: A. Solid colors that represented the deadly sins and the holy virtues, B. Country landscapes that reminded parishioners of peace, C. Interesting geometric patterns that lacked a semblance of physical beauty, D. Depictions of stories from scripture, especially those from the first five books of the Bible
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the artist behind the painting "Enthroned Madonna with Angels"? Options: A. Duccio, B. Cimabue, C. St. Benedict, D. Leonardo da Vinci Correct Option: B
Question 2: What event in the late fifth century led to the decline of physical beauty in art and the rise of metaphysical beauty in Christianity? Options: A. The construction of the city of Rome, B. The attack on Rome by the Goths, C. The discovery of perspective in art, D. The birth of Jesus Christ Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to early medieval theologians, what was considered temporary, and what was considered permanent? Options: A. Physical beauty was permanent, and virtue was temporary, B. Physical beauty was temporary, and virtue was permanent, C. Both physical beauty and virtue were temporary, D. Both physical beauty and virtue were permanent Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did St. Benedict throw himself into a thorn patch upon thinking of a beautiful woman? Options: A. He wanted to punish himself for his sinful thoughts, B. He wanted to prove his love for God, C. He feared his desire for the woman would distract him from his spiritual goals, D. He wanted to test his physical endurance Correct Option: C
Question 5: What happened to classical books that praised physical pleasures during the transition from empires to religion in European civilization? Options: A. They were widely copied and protected by monks, B. They were ignored but still survived through the centuries, C. They were not copied or protected and eventually disappeared, D. They were translated into vernacular languages Correct Option: C
Question 6: Why did medieval artists purposefully avoid aesthetically pleasing forms in their depictions of Jesus and Mary? Options: A. They lacked the skill to paint realistically, B. They wanted to emphasize the physical beauty of their subjects, C. They feared that beautiful illustrations might inspire sinful thoughts, D. They were only interested in depicting geometric patterns Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the primary goal of medieval artists when depicting Jesus and Mary, and how did it differ from modern artistic goals? Options: A. Medieval artists aimed to create realistic and beautiful depictions, while modern artists focus on abstract representations, B. Medieval artists sought to convey spiritual beauty, while modern artists prioritize physical beauty, C. Medieval artists aimed to tell stories through their art, while modern artists focus on expressing emotions, D. Medieval artists sought to create decorative pieces, while modern artists aim to create thought-provoking works Correct Option: B
Question 8: How did the rise of Christianity influence the development of art in Western Europe during the medieval period? Options: A. Christianity led to a renewed focus on physical beauty and realism in art, B. Christianity resulted in a decline in artistic production and innovation, C. Christianity led to a shift away from physical beauty and towards metaphysical and spiritual themes, D. Christianity had no significant impact on the development of art in Western Europe Correct Option: C
Question 9: What would be a likely consequence of an artist creating a beautiful and realistic depiction of Mary during the medieval period? Options: A. The artist would be praised for their skill and devotion to their craft, B. The artist would be accused of promoting sinful thoughts and desires, C. The artist would be ignored by the art community and the Church, D. The artist would be asked to create more works in a similar style Correct Option: B
Question 10: How can the depictions of Jesus and Mary in medieval art be seen as a reflection of the societal values and priorities of the time? Options: A. They demonstrate a focus on physical beauty and material wealth, B. They reflect a emphasis on spiritual beauty and virtue, C. They show a lack of artistic skill and technique, D. They represent a desire for realism and accuracy in art Correct Option: B

Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Ever see a medieval painting of baby Jesus sitting or standing on his mother's lap and wonder why she's so large? If Mary were to stand up, it seems, the angels in the picture would be as tall as her shin bone, and her torso would be disproportionately small when compared to her legs. To understand why, we need to go back to the late fifth century when the city of Rome was attacked by the Goths. Rome was built in marble and meant to last forever. It represented, for many years, the pinnacle of human civilization, so its destruction left a huge void. Theologians, who preached about a world beyond the physical, began attracting an audience as Rome crumbled, and Christianity started to fill the void left by the Empire. As a replacement for the physical beauty of Rome, Christianity offered a metaphysical beauty of virtue and an eternal heaven that could not be destroyed as Rome had. They maintained that while the physical world was temporary, virtue and religion were permanent. Beautiful objects could lead to a misguided worship of the object rather than the worship of goodness. He feared his desire for the beautiful woman would distract him from his desire to love God. The fear remained that a beautiful illustration of Mary might inspire the viewer to love the painting or the physical form of Mary, rather than the virtue she's meant to represent. So even though it may be fun to think we can paint more realistically than Cimabuey or Duccio, we need to remember that they had different goals when picking up a paintbrush.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What's the best reason (or the best reasons) Cimabue and Duccio painted a veiled, disproportionate Mary?
Options: A. They had a different goal in mind when painting, B. They didn't want to tempt people to worship the painting instead of the virtue it represented, C. They realized that Mary was not entirely mortal, as she was chosen by God, therefore must be represented differently in paintings, D. Both A and B
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The Oval Office, Inauguration Day, Rose Garden signings, and secret service agents with dark sunglasses and cool wrist radios. For a moment, forget all of it. Toss out everything you know about the President. Now, start over. What would you do if you had to invent the President? That was the question facing the 55 men who got together in secret to draw up the plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia, in the same place where the Declaration of Independence had been written eleven years earlier. Declaring independence had been risky business, demanding ferocious courage that put lives and fortunes in jeopardy. But, inventing a new government was no field day either, especially when it's summer and you're in scratchy suits, and the windows are closed because you don't want anybody to hear what you are saying, and the air conditioning doesn't work because it won't be invented for nearly 200 years. And, when you don't agree on things, it gets even hotter. For the framers, the question they argued over most while writing the Constitution and creating three branches of government had to do with the executive department. One man or three to do the job? How long should he serve? What would he really do? Who would pick him? How to get rid of him if he's doing a bad job or he's a crook? And, of course, they all meant him, and he would be a white man. The idea of a woman or an African American, for instance, holding this high office was not a glimmer in their eyes. But the framers knew they needed someone who could take charge, especially in a crisis, like an invasion or a rebellion, or negotiating treaties. Congress was not very good at making such important decisions without debates and delays. But the framers thought America needed a man who was decisive and could act quickly. They called it energy and dispatch. One thing they were dead-set against: there would be no king. They had fought a war against a country with a monarch and were afraid that one man with unchecked powers, in charge of an army, could take over the country. Instead, they settled on a president and laid out his powers in Article 2 of the Constitution. But who would choose him? Not the people, they were too liable to be misled as one framer worried. Not the legislature, that would lead to cabal and factions. Got it: electors, wise, informed men who have time to make a good decision. And if they didn't produce a winner, then the decision would go to one of the other branches of government, the Congress. The House of Representatives would step in and make the choice, which they did in 1801 and 1825. In the long, hot summer of 1787, compromises were made to invent the presidency, like counting slaves as 3/5 of a person, giving the President command of the army but Congress the power to declare war, and unlimited four-year terms. Since then, some of those compromises have been amended and the men in office have sometimes been too strong or too weak. But, if you could start from scratch, how would you redesign the Oval Office?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The men who wrote the Constitution are often referred to as the:
Options: A. New England Patriots, B. Founders, C. Framers, D. Federalists
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year did the 55 men gather in secret to draw up plans for a new American government? Options: A. 1776, B. 1787, C. 1801, D. 1825 Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary concern of the framers when deciding on the structure of the executive department? Options: A. Ensuring the President would be a woman or an African American, B. Deciding whether the President should serve a lifetime term, C. Determining whether one person or a group of people should hold the office, D. Establishing the President's role in Congress Correct Option: C
Question 3: According to the transcript, what was the primary reason the framers decided against having a king as the head of government? Options: A. They wanted to establish a monarchy, B. They were afraid of one person having unchecked powers, C. They wanted to create a system with multiple heads of state, D. They were concerned about the cost of maintaining a royal family Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the term used by the framers to describe the qualities they wanted in a President, particularly in times of crisis? Options: A. Energy and dispatch, B. Strength and courage, C. Wisdom and diplomacy, D. Integrity and honesty Correct Option: A
Question 5: Who was given the power to choose the President, according to the original plan laid out by the framers? Options: A. The people, B. The legislature, C. Electors, D. The Supreme Court Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the compromise made regarding the counting of slaves in the Constitution? Options: A. They were counted as full citizens, B. They were counted as 3/5 of a person, C. They were not counted at all, D. They were counted as 1/2 of a person Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the purpose of establishing the office of the President, according to the transcript? Options: A. To provide a figurehead for the government, B. To create a system of checks and balances, C. To ensure that important decisions could be made quickly and decisively, D. To establish a monarch-like system of government Correct Option: C
Question 8: If the electors did not produce a winner, which branch of government would step in to make the choice, according to the original plan? Options: A. The Senate, B. The House of Representatives, C. The Supreme Court, D. The Executive Branch Correct Option: B
Question 9: What was one of the concerns raised by a framer regarding the possibility of the people choosing the President? Options: A. That they would be too divided, B. That they would be too uninformed, C. That they would be too liable to be misled, D. That they would be too apathetic Correct Option: C
Question 10: If you were to redesign the Oval Office, what would be one potential consideration, based on the compromises made by the framers in the Constitution? Options: A. Establishing a system of lifetime terms for the President, B. Creating a council of advisors to make decisions for the President, C. Re-evaluating the balance of power between the President and Congress, D. Allowing the people to directly elect the President Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The Oval Office, Inauguration Day, Rose Garden signings, and secret service agents with dark sunglasses and cool wrist radios. For a moment, forget all of it. Toss out everything you know about the President. Now, start over. What would you do if you had to invent the President? That was the question facing the 55 men who got together in secret to draw up the plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia, in the same place where the Declaration of Independence had been written eleven years earlier. Declaring independence had been risky business, demanding ferocious courage that put lives and fortunes in jeopardy. But, inventing a new government was no field day either, especially when it's summer and you're in scratchy suits, and the windows are closed because you don't want anybody to hear what you are saying, and the air conditioning doesn't work because it won't be invented for nearly 200 years. And, when you don't agree on things, it gets even hotter. For the framers, the question they argued over most while writing the Constitution and creating three branches of government had to do with the executive department. One man or three to do the job? How long should he serve? What would he really do? Who would pick him? How to get rid of him if he's doing a bad job or he's a crook? And, of course, they all meant him, and he would be a white man. The idea of a woman or an African American, for instance, holding this high office was not a glimmer in their eyes. But the framers knew they needed someone who could take charge, especially in a crisis, like an invasion or a rebellion, or negotiating treaties. Congress was not very good at making such important decisions without debates and delays. But the framers thought America needed a man who was decisive and could act quickly. They called it energy and dispatch. One thing they were dead-set against: there would be no king. They had fought a war against a country with a monarch and were afraid that one man with unchecked powers, in charge of an army, could take over the country. Instead, they settled on a president and laid out his powers in Article 2 of the Constitution. But who would choose him? Not the people, they were too liable to be misled as one framer worried. Not the legislature, that would lead to cabal and factions. Got it: electors, wise, informed men who have time to make a good decision. And if they didn't produce a winner, then the decision would go to one of the other branches of government, the Congress. The House of Representatives would step in and make the choice, which they did in 1801 and 1825. In the long, hot summer of 1787, compromises were made to invent the presidency, like counting slaves as 3/5 of a person, giving the President command of the army but Congress the power to declare war, and unlimited four-year terms. Since then, some of those compromises have been amended and the men in office have sometimes been too strong or too weak. But, if you could start from scratch, how would you redesign the Oval Office?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The powers of the President are laid out in:
Options: A. Article I of the U.S. Constitution, B. Article II of the U.S. Constitution, C. The Bill of Rights, D. The Ten Commandments
Correct Option: B

Deciding whether the President should serve a lifetime term, C. Determining whether one person or a group of people should hold the office, D. Establishing the President's role in Congress Correct Option: C
Question 3: According to the transcript, what was the primary reason the framers decided against having a king as the head of government? Options: A. They wanted to establish a monarchy, B. They were afraid of one person having unchecked powers, C. They wanted to create a system with multiple heads of state, D. They were concerned about the cost of maintaining a royal family Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the term used by the framers to describe the qualities they wanted in a President, particularly in times of crisis? Options: A. Energy and dispatch, B. Strength and courage, C. Wisdom and diplomacy, D. Integrity and honesty Correct Option: A
Question 5: Who was given the power to choose the President, according to the original plan laid out by the framers? Options: A. The people, B. The legislature, C. Electors, D. The Supreme Court Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the compromise made regarding the counting of slaves in the Constitution? Options: A. They were counted as full citizens, B. They were counted as 3/5 of a person, C. They were not counted at all, D. They were counted as 1/2 of a person Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the purpose of establishing the office of the President, according to the transcript? Options: A. To provide a figurehead for the government, B. To create a system of checks and balances, C. To ensure that important decisions could be made quickly and decisively, D. To establish a monarch-like system of government Correct Option: C
Question 8: If the electors did not produce a winner, which branch of government would step in to make the choice, according to the original plan? Options: A. The Senate, B. The House of Representatives, C. The Supreme Court, D. The Executive Branch Correct Option: B
Question 9: What was one of the concerns raised by a framer regarding the possibility of the people choosing the President? Options: A. That they would be too divided, B. That they would be too uninformed, C. That they would be too liable to be misled, D. That they would be too apathetic Correct Option: C
Question 10: If you were to redesign the Oval Office, what would be one potential consideration, based on the compromises made by the framers in the Constitution? Options: A. Establishing a system of lifetime terms for the President, B. Creating a council of advisors to make decisions for the President, C. Re-evaluating the balance of power between the President and Congress, D. Allowing the people to directly elect the President Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The Oval Office, Inauguration Day, Rose Garden signings, and secret service agents with dark sunglasses and cool wrist radios. For a moment, forget all of it. Toss out everything you know about the President. Now, start over. What would you do if you had to invent the President? That was the question facing the 55 men who got together in secret to draw up the plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia, in the same place where the Declaration of Independence had been written eleven years earlier. Declaring independence had been risky business, demanding ferocious courage that put lives and fortunes in jeopardy. But, inventing a new government was no field day either, especially when it's summer and you're in scratchy suits, and the windows are closed because you don't want anybody to hear what you are saying, and the air conditioning doesn't work because it won't be invented for nearly 200 years. And, when you don't agree on things, it gets even hotter. For the framers, the question they argued over most while writing the Constitution and creating three branches of government had to do with the executive department. One man or three to do the job? How long should he serve? What would he really do? Who would pick him? How to get rid of him if he's doing a bad job or he's a crook? And, of course, they all meant him, and he would be a white man. The idea of a woman or an African American, for instance, holding this high office was not a glimmer in their eyes. But the framers knew they needed someone who could take charge, especially in a crisis, like an invasion or a rebellion, or negotiating treaties. Congress was not very good at making such important decisions without debates and delays. But the framers thought America needed a man who was decisive and could act quickly. They called it energy and dispatch. One thing they were dead-set against: there would be no king. They had fought a war against a country with a monarch and were afraid that one man with unchecked powers, in charge of an army, could take over the country. Instead, they settled on a president and laid out his powers in Article 2 of the Constitution. But who would choose him? Not the people, they were too liable to be misled as one framer worried. Not the legislature, that would lead to cabal and factions. Got it: electors, wise, informed men who have time to make a good decision. And if they didn't produce a winner, then the decision would go to one of the other branches of government, the Congress. The House of Representatives would step in and make the choice, which they did in 1801 and 1825. In the long, hot summer of 1787, compromises were made to invent the presidency, like counting slaves as 3/5 of a person, giving the President command of the army but Congress the power to declare war, and unlimited four-year terms. Since then, some of those compromises have been amended and the men in office have sometimes been too strong or too weak. But, if you could start from scratch, how would you redesign the Oval Office?

Correct Option: D

But, inventing a new government was no field day either, especially when it's summer and you're in scratchy suits, and the windows are closed because you don't want anybody to hear what you are saying, and the air conditioning doesn't work because it won't be invented for nearly 200 years. And, when you don't agree on things, it gets even hotter. For the framers, the question they argued over most while writing the Constitution and creating three branches of government had to do with the executive department. One man or three to do the job? How long should he serve? What would he really do? Who would pick him? How to get rid of him if he's doing a bad job or he's a crook? And, of course, they all meant him, and he would be a white man. The idea of a woman or an African American, for instance, holding this high office was not a glimmer in their eyes. But the framers knew they needed someone who could take charge, especially in a crisis, like an invasion or a rebellion, or negotiating treaties. Congress was not very good at making such important decisions without debates and delays. But the framers thought America needed a man who was decisive and could act quickly. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
so basically we have public leaders public officials who are out of control they're writing bills that are unintelligible and out of these bills are going to come maybe 40,000 pages of regulations total complexity which has a dramatically negative impact on our life if you're a veteran coming back from Iraq or Vietnam you face a blizzard of paperwork to get your benefits if you're trying to get a small business loan you face a blizzard of paperwork what are we going to do about it i define simplicity as a means to achieving clarity transparency and empathy building humanity into communications I've been simplifying things for 30 years I come over the out of the advertising and design business my focus is understanding you people and how you interact with the government to get your benefits how you interact with corporations decide who you're going to do business with and how you view brands so very quickly when President Obama said I don't see why we can't have a one-page plain English consumer credit agreement so I locked myself in a room figured out the content organize the document and wrote it in plain English I've had this checked by the two top consumer credit lawyers in the country this is a real thing now I want one step further and said why do we have to stick with the stodgy lawyers and just have a paper document let's go online so many people might need help in computation working with the Harvard Business School you'll see this example when you talk about minimum payments if you spend sixty two dollars for a meal the longer you take to pay out smarter planet

this organization I believe to make clarity transparency and empathy a national priority there is no way that we should allow government to communicate the way they communicate there is no way we should do business with companies that have agreements with stealth provisions and that aren't intelligible so how are we going to change the world make clarity transparency and simplicity a national priority what does a machine know about itself can it know when it needs to be repaired and when it doesn't in industries like manufacturing and energy they're using predictive analytics to detect signs of trouble helping some companies save millions on maintenance because machines seek help before they're broken and don't when they're not that's what I'm working on I'm an IBM er let's build a smarter planet

Correct Option: C

communications I've been simplifying things for 30 years I come over the out of the advertising and design business my focus is understanding you people and how you interact with the government to get
